citeinfo.title: Using Incubation Period Length as a Tool to Predict Host Impact

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Geological Survey, Biological Resources Division, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center

citeinfo.origin: U.S. Geological Survey, Biological Resources Division, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center
citeinfo.title: Brood Parasitism on Neotropical Migrants

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Geological Survey, Biological Resources Division, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center

citeinfo.othercit: This is the parent metadata for all Patuxent Wildlife Research Center brood parasitism metadata sets - Internal Filename - usgsbrdpwrc00000013.

descript.abstract: Three endangered species for which cowbird parasitism has been identified as a major factor in population decline have incubation periods > 14 days: Black-capped Vireo, Least Bell's Vireo, and Kirtland's Warbler. Twenty-five neotropical migrant species parasitized by cowbird have incubation periods of 13 days or longer, including Wood Thrush, Mountain Bluebird, Black-tailed Gnatcatcher, Swainson's Warbler, Yellow-throated Vireo, Solitary Vireo, and Hutton's Vireo.
descript.purpose: To assess the effect of brood parasitism on neotropical migrants.
descript.supplinf: Information for this metadata was adapted from the U.S. Geological Survey, Biological Resources Division, Patuxent Wildlife Research Center Showcase site at http://www.pwrc.usgs.gov/resshow/hahn1rs/hahn1rs.h tm. Internal Filename - usgsbrdpwrc00000014 - This is the "child" dataset of the parent - Brood parasitism - usgsbrdpwrc00000013. A digital copy of this metadata file is available in text, html, and sgml format on the National Biological Information Infrastructure (NBII) Metadata Clearinghouse.
